0.20.text: [percussion, bass & guitar play in bright, syncopated rhythm]

5.00.text: [The Steeles sing a wordless melody and in harmony]

38.00.text: (Gail Be) A great artist always knows

41.00.text: that the energy flows through them.

43.00.text: I believe the human part moves aside and allows--

47.00.text: God energy comes through me and starts making my stuff.

53.00.text: And the reason I'm a great artist,

54.00.text: I know how to move over and let the energy come through me.

58.00.text: And that's what people feel when they get close to my dresses

61.00.text: or great art, the energy of the person making it

65.00.text: comes out and they get drawn in, and they're not really sure why,

70.00.text: but I believe great art comes spiritually.

72.76.text: [drums & synthesizer play a heavy rock beat]

80.00.text: (Gail) I would call my work my art,

83.00.text: and I do art in fashion

88.00.text: It started by, one of my friends

96.00.text: And even then, when I started to learn that,

99.00.text: I was still adding Swarovski and making them

101.00.text: instead of traditional, more modern and pretty.

104.00.text: And those are my 4 classes I'd ever taken.

107.00.text: Beading is actually learned by practice

112.00.text: beaded incessantly from the minute I started.

115.00.text: And then I have been gifted

117.00.text: with this ability to do this; that's what I believe.

126.24.text: [Sound of glass beads being rifled through]

139.00.text: I began collecting beads 24 years ago.

143.00.text: I'd been diagnosed in 1989 with keratoconus

147.00.text: and while I was beading, my cornea ruptured.

150.00.text: And then the next one the next year also ruptured.

153.00.text: All of a sudden your sight's just gone,

155.00.text: and I was unable to bead for about 5 years.

158.00.text: I just really wanted to stay connected with beads.

162.00.text: And I collected beads, becoming a connoisseur

165.00.text: of the rarest beads, and then overnight, from 3 surgeries,

169.00.text: I saw 20/20, and then I had this awesome collection

173.00.text: and I started beading with that.

174.00.text: These are all vintage beads from Germany in the 1940s and '50s.

179.00.text: And what I do then is pour them out

182.00.text: and then I divide each of them into a color.

188.00.text: and that's because I'm pulling energy

191.00.text: back and forth for them to know I'm going to start using them

195.00.text: and me to get in my mind what colors I have,

198.00.text: 'cause once I start, I don't stop.

201.00.text: All my dresses that I come up with

203.00.text: I actually see them before I start.

205.00.text: It's a vision that comes in very quickly.

207.00.text: And since I don't sketch or draw or do mathematical calculations,

212.00.text: it's that one second of seeing the dress,

214.00.text: then I go through, and I see what beads I can match

217.00.text: and then pull them out of all the different compartments

220.00.text: and put them all together, and then I start working.

231.00.text: and there are even more people that sew.

234.00.text: And no one is doing fully-beaded dresses like me.

239.00.text: And to be an artist, you have to find a niche

242.00.text: of what nobody else is doing.

249.00.text: This is the Holy Grail of my whole business.

252.00.text: This is like the holy sanctuary, basically our temple or church

258.00.text: I work with many different textures and style of beads.

262.00.text: I like to work with vintage because of the energy of that

267.00.text: and they are pristine-- that means no one's worn them,

273.00.text: This is just a very small amount of my vintage beads.

277.00.text: These are the oldest that you could get ones, made in Austria,

281.00.text: and I feel very honored every time I'm doing these packages

285.00.text: because that's the joy of doing

287.00.text: and being able to get what I've got.

289.00.text: I get to do this all the time, and I do not take it for granted.

299.00.text: For me, I feel like I've been keeper of the beads,

301.00.text: and the way I kept 'em is to put 'em into dresses.

304.00.text: This is a Silver Star Flower

305.00.text: and this is the first piece that was ever made.

309.00.text: Silver Star Flower being my first piece,

311.00.text: I started it and didn't stop.

313.00.text: This is the outfit that Lady Gaga wore with Tony Bennett,

316.00.text: on their new CD, Anything Goes.

318.00.text: The entertainment industry I decided was really going to be

321.00.text: my beginning goal and the end goal being in museums.

332.00.text: And now that I know I can make these dresses, I thought,

337.00.text: how am I going to get the world to pay attention to them?

342.00.text: [women sing a capella in the style of Gregorian chant]

356.00.text: (Gail) Fantasy is the white wedding dress

360.00.text: with the most amount of beads.

369.00.text: She's made by 23 women over 3 years.

372.00.text: So Fantasy was specifically made to leave a great,

377.00.text: great, great piece of art for centuries,

380.00.text: and I think she's one of the most

382.00.text: amazing pieces of art in the world.

390.18.text: (woman) Well, we're doing the placement of the crystal belt.

395.00.text: When I first started, most of my pieces were taking over a year.

399.00.text: And there's no way I could put together enough

402.00.text: if my goal was to be doing museums.

405.00.text: And my team and I worked together

407.00.text: to try to learn different parts of dresses or making them up.

427.00.text: but they have a desire to be creative.

429.00.text: Most of them have a background in either making jewelry

432.00.text: or making dresses, and usually both, and hand-sewing.

436.00.text: So what I would do right now for me is,

438.00.text: get a piece of paper in there and draw me that

444.00.text: (Gail) When I go to the studio, I'm helping my team

446.00.text: on each part of their project that they're doing.

449.00.text: I teach them how to put things together,

452.00.text: but they're creative on their own.

459.00.text: I'm so glad it's on there finally.

461.00.text: Yea! Look at how pretty she is.

463.00.text: This'll be all solid beads, so when this

465.00.text: gets up on the red carpet, it will just explode.

468.00.text: Temptress because she has fabric is the first dress

471.00.text: that we are trying to get on the red carpet with.

474.00.text: This looks like a million cameras going off, and this is in semi dark.

478.00.text: This comes on with the spotlight in full dark-- it's insane.

482.00.text: I started doing fabric a year ago because a company in LA

488.00.text: had called me and wanted Eden for The Grammy's.

490.00.text: And I said you can't sit in it, you can't walk down the runway,

494.00.text: it's heavy and if you want to be in this business,

497.00.text: they've got to sit down for award shows

499.00.text: and they have to be able to walk the red carpet.

506.00.text: This is how we work-- we design all night,

509.00.text: into the wee hours of the night, then I go bead,

512.00.text: because I bead at night, I get up,

513.00.text: we have dinner, and then we start in all over again.

518.00.text: When you're going to do something great, you need

520.00.text: to jump off a cliff and believe you're going to be shown.

539.00.text: The reason I bead by myself at night

542.00.text: is that there are no interruptions.

545.00.text: The real beading for me is in private.

550.00.text: The reason I keep making my dresses and doing this is

554.00.text: to leave them for the world.

555.00.text: I think it's a complete waste when you have been given

560.00.text: gifted abilities to not use them,

562.00.text: and so I feel a responsibility to do that and out of all that,

567.00.text: fortunately, I really love to bead.

569.00.text: So every day that I'm beading, or every night,

572.00.text: I give thanks for allowing me to do something I love.

594.56.text: [guitars and percussion play in moderate, steady rhythm]

612.64.text: (Patrick K. Pryor) In every house I've lived in I've always made repairs

615.00.text: and fixed it up in some way, and so I've been

618.00.text: working on little projects every couple of months.

621.00.text: So it looks like there's several layers of wallpaper.

624.00.text: This is probably the original, closest to the plaster, then

626.00.text: there's some paint and then some other wallpaper on top of that.

630.00.text: This is kind of the analogous part to my painting

633.00.text: is that I'm actually laying down layers that I later uncover,

638.00.text: but exactly how they get uncovered is the unknown part.

643.50.text: It's interesting that becoming an artist was synonymous

645.74.text: with starting to learn how to work on an old house.

655.48.text: I was about 3 years old at my father's house.

658.00.text: He was a great drawer, my grandfather was a great artist,

662.00.text: and he would teach me how to draw.

666.42.text: When I first started painting, I was trying to make paintings

673.00.text: I was trying to make them larger and in color.

676.00.text: And then I found when I used many, many layers I could

680.00.text: add depth to the paintings and using transparent layers

683.00.text: and scraping and sanding, I can add even more layers

686.00.text: and combinations than I can with just using the brush.

689.00.text: I tried so many different things in painting.

692.00.text: I feel like my work changes almost every couple of years.

695.00.text: I have certain stylistic patterns that people recognize,

699.00.text: but I've been experimenting a lot.

721.60.text: Using layers allows transformation to happen

724.00.text: and allows me to work with something that's already there.

729.00.text: Oftentimes when I start a painting,

731.00.text: I have to create a painting that I'll then react to.

748.00.text: After I have that base layer on the painting,

751.00.text: then I'll start laying down these lines using tape.

755.00.text: The lines in the painter's tape was an important way

759.00.text: for me to have some stability in the composition,

764.00.text: some sort of a foundation, because frankly,

767.00.text: the idea of working on a blank canvas is daunting.

771.00.text: I try to start some paintings that way and I just can't do it,

775.00.text: so I have to have some sort of structure in place first,

782.00.text: This is always such a bittersweet process, it's like

785.00.text: kind of wrecking something I've been spending so much time on.

797.14.text: Then I start covering everything up with the white paint,

800.00.text: and I've tried lots of different colors, other tonal qualities.

807.00.text: the purity of the white paint

808.00.text: that's important for me to use as the next layer

813.00.text: And then that white layer allows me to scrape through

816.00.text: to then reveal the color and the lines beneath it.

820.00.text: [soft scraping ans sound of squirt bottle]

833.00.text: I tend to work in series and this most recent body of work

837.00.text: was inspired by experimenting in the studio.

840.00.text: I come up with all the ideas

842.00.text: and ways of doing things by experimenting.

845.00.text: [Dobro and mandolin play in bright rhythm]

861.50.text: The calligraphic mark making that I use

863.34.text: is the hardest thing to explain.

864.92.text: It's been the thing that I've done the longest.

866.66.text: It's been the, you know, it's been my drawings that I do

870.82.text: since I was a young child,

872.00.text: and they are very much a meditative process.

875.00.text: It's the reference in this new series of works that connects

879.00.text: to every other painting that I've done in the past.

884.02.text: So this is the first painting where I discovered the process

888.00.text: that I've been exploring, and I like it so much because

893.62.text: I did things in the painting that I wouldn't do again,

896.00.text: so there's a certain amount of like naivete about the painting,

899.00.text: not knowing what I had in mind, which is what makes the painting

904.22.text: so good in my mind and why I like it so much

906.64.text: is because I didn't have any expectations and therefore,

910.00.text: I was free to explore and free to discover.

916.88.text: it allows me to sort of discover meaning.

918.00.text: I feel like there's something to discover,

920.00.text: it's like a code, a secret code

922.00.text: that will reveal something if you look at it long enough.

926.00.text: I think this series of work is

928.00.text: the most exciting work that I've ever done.

1037.00.text: (J.D.) We grew up in Gary, Indiana.

1039.00.text: My father was the early encouragement for us

1041.00.text: because he was the guitar player and he would take us

1044.00.text: to sing at places all over.

1046.00.text: And our dad was, he was everything.

1047.64.text: He was the total catalyst or us, that got us out there

1053.26.text: I was the first sibling to come to Minnesota in 1976.

1056.00.text: I was working in corporate America at the time,

1060.00.text: and started moonlighting at the Children's Theatre

1063.48.text: and at Mixed Blood Theatre, and then when Fred came in town,

1067.00.text: he and I became a duet

1069.00.text: and started working with choirs together.

1071.00.text: And then when Jearlyn came along,

1072.00.text: the three of us started singing and doing a variety of things.

1076.00.text: We won the Minnesota State Fair Amateur Contest

1079.00.text: and we took our little $500 winnings, I think it was,

1083.00.text: and we were recording a demo,

1085.00.text: and things just snowballed from there.

1088.00.text: (J.D.) And then Jevetta came along and stole the show

1091.00.text: and Billy's just hangin' on for dear life!

1097.34.text: We'll take that target off your shirt.

1098.44.text: And think about when he first, as the first sibling

1101.00.text: in 1876 to be here, you know, raising the flag

1104.00.text: of The Steeles coming-- it was awesome! [all laugh]

1268.06.text: (Jevetta) We're not the first generation of Steele singers.

1270.68.text: This was a legacy passed down to us.

1273.32.text: Our grandfather was a singer with his siblings, our dad

1276.00.text: who was also a musician, he played guitar.

1279.00.text: He and his siblings sang, and they recorded gospel music.

1283.00.text: So passing it on to us was very, very natural.

1286.00.text: To see all of us get together

1289.00.text: at a family gathering-- everybody sang.

1291.00.text: (singing) The way you changed my life

1297.00.text: Oh no they can't take that away from me

1303.00.text: No they can't take that away

1313.28.text: (Billy) The reason why we called it The Colors of Gershwin,

1315.00.text: we wanted to put our colors to it.

1317.00.text: We tried to stay with all traditional melodies

1320.00.text: and whatever spin we put on,

1321.00.text: we tried to stick with that as close as we could.

1324.00.text: Once the arrangements were done, it came together really well.

1326.00.text: J.D. does an incredible job of putting a set list together

1330.00.text: and having a flow that makes a lot of sense,

1333.00.text: and that's part of his responsibility.

1335.00.text: And I disagreed with his flow, however, he was correct.

1339.00.text: And that's the thing that we realized is that

1341.00.text: in all of our positions within the family, is that

1344.00.text: we really do understand who is supposed to do what.

1347.00.text: 'Cause every one of the writers in the family

1349.00.text: or arrangers in the family have a different style of doing it.

1352.00.text: So J.D.'s way of doing it is not to make any notes.

1355.00.text: If you were to look at the lyrics on his sheet of paper,

1359.00.text: there's not one scratch, not one check, not a word written.

1362.00.text: Jevetta on the other hand, knows exactly, everything

1364.00.text: is written down, she's typed up all the background

1367.42.text: so she hears in her head and she goes this is what I'm hearing

1370.00.text: and this is what I want you to do.

1372.54.text: Fred comes in with his keyboard,

1374.16.text: and he sits down and he looks over at us and says,

1377.00.text: this is what I want Jearlyn, you sing this.

1380.00.text: Billy comes in with tracks; he's the one

1382.00.text: that constantly works on the nuances with us.

1384.00.text: Every one of them, their arrangements or their writing

1387.00.text: is, it has a purpose, it is just not happenstance.

1392.00.text: And we can do the clarinet, just break it down

1395.00.text: a little bit on that. (Jearlyn) That'd be great.

1396.00.text: (Billy) Then when we come back, come back to all the big stuff.

1488.80.text: and we think it was a great success.
